Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Expectation2: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation2: On the final day of the quarter, the team must hit the cumulative target to avoid penalties and secure bonuses.
Story: I stared at my phone, the clock ticking closer to the start of the family ceremony. My stepmother’s voice echoed in my mind, reminding me how important it was for me to lead the ritual this year—“It’s your turn to show you’re truly part of this family.” I could feel the weight of her expectations, the hope that I’d finally bridge the gap between us by honoring their traditions. But my headset buzzed with reminders from my manager: “We’re behind on sales. Every call counts. If we don’t hit the target today, everyone loses out.” My team was counting on me, and I needed the bonus as much as anyone. My hands trembled as I weighed the script in one hand and the ceremonial candle in the other. I could hear my family gathering in the next room, waiting for me, while my phone screen flashed with the next lead. My heart pounded, torn between the family I was trying to belong to and the job that kept me afloat. I stood frozen, caught between two worlds, each demanding all of me at the same time.
